Understate: The claim may understate the effectiveness of COVID-19 vaccines in protecting people from getting the disease. The expert's verdict states that research shows the vaccines are effective at protecting people from getting COVID-19.
Problematic assumption: The claim may make a problematic assumption by suggesting that Dr. Fauci said vaccines don't protect against COVID-19. The expert's verdict clarifies that Fauci was referring to the distinction between preventing the disease and preventing infection with the virus.
Lack enough support: The claim may lack enough support as it is based on a viral video posted on Instagram. The expert's verdict provides additional context and information to understand Fauci's statement.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim may not consider alternative explanations for Fauci's statement. The expert's verdict explains that Fauci was discussing the possibility of vaccinated individuals still being able to carry and transmit the virus, not the effectiveness of the vaccines in preventing the disease.
Contradict fact: The claim may contradict the fact that COVID-19 vaccines are effective at protecting people from getting the disease. The expert's verdict confirms that research shows the vaccines are effective in preventing COVID-19.
Falters at times: It is difficult to determine if the claim falters at times without more specific information.
